ResponseText: I don't see them asking for names. Seems to me it's an attempt to address rumours and correct misconceptions.
I wonder if we can report the white house website as misinformation. Afterall, the CBO and factcheck.org already debunked a lot of their BS. But yes, that does seem a little fishy in and of itself.

QuoteText: Apparently, the white house has set up a website where we can report each other for spreading misinformation about the Healthcare bill. On the Whitehouse Website... The White House - Blog Post - Facts Are Stubborn Things What exactly is this for? Are they taking names or are they just trying to fix misconceptions about what's actually in the bill? It concerns me when our govt. begins asking citizens to begin monitoring each other and sending the names in. It would concern me regardless of what the topic was.
ResponseText: Here is a perfect example ONCE AGAIN of the double standards and blatant hypocrisy which defines the Liberal Left at every single level of rationale. ResponseText: Yeah, thought so. Bye Archie. Back on topic- I don't agree with reporting people's names, email addresses, personal info of any kind. But I can see the advantage of reporting misinformation so that it can be corrected. I see the advantage in making sure people are making an educated decision, rather than one based on partisan rumours and fear mongering. If this is the case, seems like a good, cheap way to see what kind of misinformation is floating aroung, collect it, and address it.

ResponseText: Two questions though... how are we to know that there isn't going to be some sort of collection of names and such (though I'm no conspiracy theorist). Of course the govt. is a huge entity and its hard to imagine them taking the time to vindictively go after some small potatoes (however, dropping someone's name to the IRS for an Audit isn't that hard lol). Its just strikes me as weird that they want you to send in a private email, seems to me they'd just address anything they want on an open website and be done with it. The other question is, how can we know that the info THEY are giving out is unbiased and neutral? I mean, they obviously have a stake in their plan. Why should we suspend disbelief for them... even if someone's on my 'side' I'll still look critically at any plan they have that will affect me.

ResponseText: We don't, and as I said, if there is I completely disagree with it. Like you said, if someone wanted to report someone else to have them harassed by the government, could they not just put in an anonymous call to the IRS and say "Don't you think it's odd that my neighbour says he delivers newspapers for a living, but lives in a 10 bedroom mansion with a big swimming pool? Where do you think he gets that money from?" Or call social services and say "My kid has a classmate who comes to school with bruises all the time, and he says he falls down the stairs. Seems to me the kid is a little too much of a clutz, if you get what I'm saying..." Point being, if you wanted to get someone in trouble with the government, there are lots of easier ways to do it already available. Same way you know anything the government tells you is unbiased and neutral Who's asking anyone to suspend disbelief? All I'm saying is you have people like Archie running around screaming that Obama is going to enslave you for reason x,y and z. You send in an email saying "I heard x, y, and z. Is that true?" And you have the white house, in a press briefing or on the web site say "Some people have said x, y, and z. That's incorrect, and here's why", rather than having people believe whatever rumour catches their fancy.

And didn't Nazi Germany require the loyal citizens to report those who were disloyal to the Nationalist Socialist Program?
